repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Implements idea from issue #1664 
- [x] Create `runtime/defaults.vim` (definition of contents ongoing)
- [x] Load `runtime/defaults.vim` from `main.c:source_startup_scripts()`.
- [x] Update `runtime/doc/starting.txt`.
- [x] Fix handling of `-u` arguments, so `-u NONE` doesn't load these defaults.

Notes: `defaults.vim` is mostly based on vim-sensible. I removed feature checks since they are unneded in neovim.

comment_data.body: You should not use `map` without `nore` here. Also `search()` is a waste of CPU here: just check that `getline('.')[: col('.')-1] =~# '^\s\+$'`. Another variant: `virtcol('.') - 1 == indent('.')` (will jump to the beginning of text in case cursor is inside the indentation, full equivalent is `virtcol('.') - 1 <= indent('.') && col('.') > 1`).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,73 @@
+" early.vim
+"
+" configurations to set earliest
+"
+" based on tpope's sensible.vim[1], with some suggestions gathered 
+" at neovim's issue #276[2]
+"
+" [1]: https://github.com/tpope/vim-sensible
+" [2]: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/276
+
+filetype plugin indent on
+syntax enable
+
+set autoindent
+set backspace=indent,eol,start
+set complete-=i
+set smarttab
+
+set nrformats-=octal
+
+set ttimeout
+set ttimeoutlen=100
+
+set incsearch
+set hlsearch
+" use <C-L> to clear the highlighting of :set hlsearch.
+if maparg('<C-L>', 'n') ==# ''
+    nnoremap <silent> <C-L> :nohlsearch<CR><C-L>
+endif
+
+set mouse=a
+
+set laststatus=2
+set ruler
+set showcmd
+set wildmenu
+set wildmode=list:longest
+
+set scrolloff=1
+set sidescrolloff=5
+set display+=lastline
+
+set encoding=utf-8
+
+set listchars=tab:>\ ,trail:-,extends:>,precedes:<,nbsp:+
+
+set formatoptions+=j
+
+" search upwards for tags file
+setglobal tags-=./tags  tags^=./tags;
+
+set autoread
+set fileformats+=mac
+
+set history=1000
+set tabpagemax=50
+set viminfo^=!
+set sessionoptions-=options
+
+if &t_Co == 8 && $TERM !~# '^linux'
+    set t_Co=16
+endif
+
+if &shell =~# 'fish$'
+    set shell=sh
+endif
+
+" allow undoing <C-u> (delete text typed in the current line)
+inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
+
+" <home> goes to the beginning of the text on first press 
+" and the beginning of the line on second. it alternates afterwards
+map <expr> <home> search('^\s\+\%#', 'n') ? '0' : '_'

comment_data.body: `virtcol()` + `indent()` is two orders of magnitude faster in a file with 1800 lines, 3 orders of magnitude for 20000 lines, etc. You need to supply `, line('.')` as an additional argument to `search()` to make them take the same time to finish that is not dependent on the amount of lines in the current file.

comment_data.body: :+1: Will change that. I just copied that from the #276 thread, I was really more interested in hearing if people were OK with this set of defaults.

comment_data.body: How about `default.vim` ?
Or `defaults.vim`?

I don't think we need to check `maparg()` because nothing could possibly be mapped at stage 1 of the init.

However, this raises the question of how this will affect existing plugins which check this map. They will behave differently in Neovim than Vim. 

We could change the actual internal definition of `<c-l>` to clear `hlsearch`, such that this mapping is not necessary; but then that could break some other plugin. I can't imagine what it would break, so maybe it is acceptable for this case.

comment_data.body: I wouldn't mind changing that. `defaults.vim` sounds best to me.

> We could change the actual internal definition of `<c-l>` to clear `hlsearch`, such that this mapping is not necessary; but then that could break some other plugin. I can't imagine what it would break, so maybe it is acceptable for this case.

AFAIK this will only change `v:hlsearch` variable (which is rather recent addition) and `screenattr()` (which is intended for testing only).

comment_data.body: I don't like this. When I execute `:!cmd` or `system()`, I expect fish to process the expression as things like `dir/**.ext` glob differently with `sh` and `bash`. Vim supports the fish shell, though, admittedly, some plugins do not.

comment_data.body: Actually, it seems like I tested this in vim instead of nvim. In nvim the behavior is different, and the default seems OK (as OK as having nvim yielding to the terminal is, but I'm not sure if that's a problem on my end or a quirk in nvims implementation of `:!`). Either way, I'll remove this.

comment_data.body: Actually, since evim is going away, I don't think we need defaults.vim. We can put the defaults in the system `nvimrc`. We need to add that to `runtime/` since it does not appear to exist.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -763,11 +763,17 @@ accordingly.  Vim proceeds in this order:
 	If Vim was started in Ex mode with the "-s" argument, all following
 	initializations until 4. are skipped.  Only the "-u" option is
 	interpreted.
+
+                                                        *defaults.vim*
+     a. $VIMRUNTIME/defaults.vim is loaded first of all. This script sets some
+        basic settings which should be desirable for everyone. These defaults
+        are set here so the behavior of "set all&" is not changed (see |:set-&|).
+
 							*evim.vim*
-     a. If vim was started as |evim| or |eview| or with the |-y| argument, the
+     b. If vim was started as |evim| or |eview| or with the |-y| argument, the
 	script $VIMRUNTIME/evim.vim will be loaded.
 							*system-vimrc*
-     b. For Unix, MS-DOS, MS-Windows, VMS, Macintosh, and Amiga,
+     c. For Unix, MS-DOS, MS-Windows, VMS, Macintosh, and Amiga,

comment_data.body: Yeah, I placed it separatedly because of what was before discussed when I proposed to initialize the plugin hosts from the system nvimrc. I was left with the impression that it would be something that only distributors would want to touch, so the idea was to have defaults.vim be one layer below that. This way these defaults are guaranteed not to be messed up with by system admins or packagers. But whatever approach is fine.

comment_data.body:
>  I was left with the impression that it would be something that only distributors would want to touch

I thought about that, but who suggested that we can't distribute a "recommended nvimrc"? 

In fact I think the practice of distros modifying the system nvimrc should be stopped in most cases. In most cases the distro is trying to correct Vim's own inertia, whereas with Neovim we want to solve this upstream. We want a consistent experience for all users.

I would like to hear opinions from package maintainers though.

comment_regular_data.body:
Thanks for getting this started. We will need to let it marinate for a few weeks to gather hate mail :)

Regarding Y to y$, quoting the [original objection](https://github.com/tpope/vim-sensible/issues/47):

> To override settings in vim-sensible, I would have to break my vimrc into two different files in different directories in order to have them load at the correct times. That makes inspection, editing, and deployment of my vimrc on multiple machines rather more complicated

This doesn't apply to Neovim because we apply these settings before sourcing .nvimrc, so overriding them is comfortable. I think we should map `Y` to `y$`.

> I was also thinking if perhaps some common workarounds would be good to have there too, like this for tmux/screen.

I'm very hesitant to set terminal codes, it's considered bad practice. It should be done in .bashrc, etc.

> Thanks for getting this started. We will need to let it marinate for a few weeks to gather hate mail :)

In this case, we can probably redirect that to tpope/vim-sensible :p 

> I think we should map Y to y$.

I'll add it, then. As you said, we should gather more data on what shouldn't be set as default as time goes on. On that note, I'll add

```
runtime! macros/matchit.vim
unlet g:loaded_matchit " allow a user installed matchit version to be resourced
```

too.

> I'm very hesitant to set terminal codes.

What about `set t_Co=16`. Do you think we shouldn't have that here either?

> What about set t_Co=16.

That seems like something we may be able to fix internally.
Ok, then, I'll remove that too. Could you open a new issue to make note of these things?
@fmoralesc I don't have a clear idea about what to do with t_Co right now, so let's leave it in there for now.
@justinmk OK, I re-introduced it.

The discussion at #1656 made me think about this a bit, and I believe the current implementation might be better than using the system wide vimrc for setting these defaults. Two reasons:

1) We ensure these defaults are set if nvim is installed properly. This allows for simplification of some files like we've seen in `evim.vim`, which sustantially becomes [this](https://gist.github.com/fmoralesc/d7f39118932fadbe1d29)
2) The system admin should feel free to provide some system wide defaults without them being overwritten on updates. 

Now, 2) is the weaker argument. The system wide vimrc is mostly unused nowadays like this, and is mostly handled by the distributors. However, having the defaults.vim file be separate and load first in initialization seems more flexible and allows for packagers and system-admins to do whatever they could need.

What about lazyredraw? See here: https://github.com/tpope/vim-sensible/issues/78

Echoing what a user in the linked thread said, I'm not aware of any downsides to it, but if there are please say so.
Sure.
Added `lazyredraw`. (I hope this time the build goes through.)

I guess the tests would have to be adapted for this change. But, aren't the test failures an indication that this change might also break many user scripts?

Also: for me, 'default' means _what I get if I start vim with `-u NONE -U NONE`_ and _what I get if I run `:set all&`_. After this PR, the two would differ (as you mentioned, but still: I find this highly undesirable).

I'd like to propose a different approach, which is inspired by i3wm (a tiling window manager, that is fully keyboard driven):
  If no local config file is found, something like this is asked:

```
There is no local configuration file installed. 
Please choose one of the following options:
a) use nvim defaults and don't ask again (recommended)
[writes a local configuration file]
b) use vim defaults and don't ask again (if you don't know what this means, choose a)) 
[writes an empty local config]
```

This probably shouldn't be triggered for `-u NONE`.

I could make it so `nvim -u NONE` doesn't load the defaults file. I think that is the better behavior. I just tested it and it fixes the error for the functionaltests.

On the other hand, I don't like that proposal because there are some gains if we set those defaults before the system and user vimrcs. We wouldn't be propagating better defaults for people who already have configuration files set up, for one.

OK. So now `functionaltests` pass, but there are issues with `oldtest`:

```
test32 FAILED " insert expansion
test36 FAILED " character classes in regexp
test37 FAILED " scrollbind
test38 FAILED " virtual replace mode
test39 FAILED " visual block mode commands
test45 FAILED " folding
test58 NO OUTPUT " spell checking (stalled)
test59 NO OUTPUT " spell checking with encoding set to utf-8 (stalled)
test69 FAILED " multi-byte text formatting
test73 FAILED " find completion
test88 FAILED " correct display with conceal and tabulators
test91 FAILED " get[buf,win,tab,tabwin]bar()
test92 FAILED " mksession saves cursor columns correctly ...
test93 FAILED " idem, latin1
test107 FAILED " adjusting window and contents
test_listlbr FAILED " linebreak and list
test_listlbr_utf8 FAILED " idem, utf-8
test_breakindent FAILED " breakindent
```

This is caused by me using a naive method on the detection of the -u NONE arg, so `nvim -u NONE` doesn't load defaults.vim, but `nvim -u NONE -u other.vim` does. Anyway, it is interesting to know that these are the things that behave differently with the proposed defaults.

On December 17, 2014 6:53:13 AM EAT, Felipe Morales notifications@github.com wrote:

> Added `lazyredraw`. (I hope this time the build goes through.)
> 
> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/1667#issuecomment-67273918

:set lazyredraw causes Command-T to "freeze" Vim if it appears that switching to some buffer or opening some file requires some sort of confirmation: YCM question regarding whether to load its configuration file, Vim question regarding whether to load externally changed file, ... these dialogs still require user action, but they are not visible.
@ZyX-I thanks for the input, I'll remove it then.

I think the issue with `-u` and this can be solved two ways:

1) turn `-u` into an accumulator-style setting, so we can have a series of init files to load serially. If NONE appears in this list, defaults.vim won't be loaded.
2) create a flag like `-nodefaults` to disable the loading of defaults.vim and add this to the tests invocations.
I implemented a third option, which I believe is cleaner. If vim ever finds -u NONE when parsing the arguments, it will set up a flag not to load the defaults.vim file.

Any thoughts on `splitright` and `splitbelow`? I find them more intuitive than their respective counterparts, as they don't move the previous focused window off to the right/bottom, which might seem a bit jarring. Then again, one might want a newly open window to be the primary focus, I'm not really sure.

@Pyrohh I'm not sure about those. `splitbelow` feels really weird for me now that I'm testing it (surely just the habit), and it might be a bit jarring as a default for experienced users. `splitright` is not that bad.

@fmoralesc Yes, it might be jarring for experienced users, but I think an intuitive interface is more important (at least in this case since it's a relatively small change).

Example: I'm looking at `main.c`, and I'd like to open `main.h`. Given that most languages read left to right (or at least the ones present in nvim's translations), it seems more logical to me to open the split on the right, thereby avoiding moving the initial buffers contents at all, only reducing its right bound before not displaying text (or wrapping, depending on the users vimrc). I think the same could be said for opening splits on the bottom, since most of the languages nvim supports are read top down.

If a user plans on opening a file which isn't complimentary to their currently open buffer (such as their `~/.vimrc`), then they could just use `:e`. My point is that when opening splits, the initial buffer's position shouldn't be replaced by the new buffer's ones by default, as nvim has no idea whether the second buffer is complementary to the old buffer or not.

All that might have been a bit convoluted to parse, so I'll provide clarification if needed.

edit: for clarity

@Pyrohh Yes, I can see all that, and I'm not opposed in principle to include it in this PR. I checked, and that behavior is pretty common in other editors (it is emacs' default). I just would want to hear more opinions on it, though.
splitright and splitbelow are not worth debating because there is no clear advantage. Some like it, some don't, it's arbitrary. Err on the side of tradition here.
@justinmk Yeah, I thought so too.
@justinmk Perhaps, but there's only been two opinions mentioned so far in this thread.

Took a look at github statistics, and found, from a total of [~164k vimrcs](https://github.com/search?l=vim&p=3&q=vimrc&ref=searchresults&type=Code&utf8=%E2%9C%93), [~40k](https://github.com/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=splitbelow&type=Code&ref=searchresults) set `splitbelow`, [~35k](https://github.com/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=splitright&type=Code&ref=searchresults) set `splitright`, [~8,5k](https://github.com/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=nosplitbelow&type=Code&ref=searchresults) set `nosplitbelow` and [~7,3k](https://github.com/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=nosplitright&type=Code&ref=searchresults) set `nosplitright`. It actually surprised me that so many people used `splitbelow` and `splitright`, but they are still used by only a minority of users from this sample. Of course these numbers are very coarse, but they give some kind of sense of the rate of usage.

@Pyrohh (bless his robotic soul) made me revisit this PR, so I just rebased to master and cleaned up the commit history. It seems like the issues with the tests are gone (possibly because some of the old tests were removed), so I would like to reopen the discussion for the inclusion of this patch into neovim.

Again, the point of it is to provide a better user experience "out of the box", which can help differenciate between vim and nvim (think about the rise in popularity of the fish shell because of its imho no-nonsense approach to defaults.) As to the replacement of the hard coded default settings, we might use the `defaults.vim` file as a guideline as to what needs to be done, if we finally settle on its contents (which I believe are good enough as they are).

@fmoralesc I do want to go in this direction, but it should be done by changing the actual defaults, so that `set foo&vim` restores the default, as well as `set &all`. This may require a separate PR for each option change (approximately).
@justinmk I know, but I'm intending this as a transitional step towards that.
But the transition is extra work. Adding it and later removing it, adds complication.

Fair enough. But taking this transitional step will help define what work is actually needed (as in, people will know which settings' defaults should be changed) and it allows for also testing which settings are _really_ good as defaults.

Besides, some of the stuff included in the current `defaults.vim` can't be handled the same way (sourcing the matchit plugin and the mappings).

@justinmk Currently for every option, there is a 'Vi default' and a 'Vim default' in `option.c`. I'm starting to refactor `option.c` to remove all 'Vi defaults' for options. This will make `option.c` more readable and also make it easier to implement the change proposed in this pull request directly in `option.c`.

I assume there is no plan to have two separate sets of defaults in the code in Neovim at some point?

@yagebu 

>  I'm starting to refactor option.c to remove all 'Vi defaults' for options

No, please don't. There were 3 other PRs to do this.

> This will make option.c more readable

Not really, it doesn't even save many lines.

> also make it easier to implement the change proposed in this pull request directly in option.c.

Maybe I'm missing something, but I do not see how that would be.

See also:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/228#issuecomment-67878227

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/2071#issuecomment-90273078

>  sets of defaults in the code in Neovim at some point?

Haven't decided. Removing the Vi defaults doesn't do anything but break `set foo&vi` for no reason--it doesn't reduce complexity.

> Removing the Vi defaults doesn't do anything but break set foo&vi for no reason.

Reverting to a vi-compatible value should be considered as meaningless and treated as a no-op, imho. I _know_ this will break the behavior of any script that does it, but the point is it's best to promote being explicit. I mean, what sense is there in a plugin setting a vi-compatible value in nvim? I believe `set op&vi` should only be used by a script that has detected (n)vim is running in compatible mode, which is no longer relevant in nvim...

Well, a Vi default for an option is just a value. The fact that it is the same value that is used by Vi is really a superficial coincidence. If someone is using `set foo&vi` for whatever reason, do we have a good reason to break it? It doesn't save _us_ much.

Also, my feeling on this has always been that it's something that can wait until after first release, when we have 10x as many users. _Then_ it will be easy to know if there's any point in keeping it around. Why add this potential extra friction to new users right now?

@justinmk To be clear, I agree it's low priority, and it doesn't save us much code-wise. I think there is the chance to clean up the semantics of the viml language in this point, and I think it's worth it. There is a difference between the _sense_ of "assigning a value of 100 to `&history`" and "assigning `&history` the value vi had", and I think allowing the second is not worth it (to be fair, I think the whole `set -&` deal is currently a misfeature. User wise, what is really needed is something like `set -&vimrc`, but that would require much more work...)

@justinmk Good thing I didn't really get started yet then :D Forgot to search the closed PRs too so I didn't see them.

> > also make it easier to implement the change proposed in this pull request directly in option.c.
> 
> Maybe I'm missing something, but I do not see how that would be.

Easier is maybe the wrong word, since all of this is only about mechanically moving pieces of code anyway. But the way the array of options works now, if someone changes the Vim default but forgets  to remove the `P_VI_DEF` flag then Vi's default would still be used. Not going to happen if you're careful of course, but would be prevented completely if there only was one default. Overall it's not a real issue and probably more of an aestetic thing.

The reason why I looked into this is that I saw that all the `{Not in Vi}` references in the docs were removed. But there are still some options where the different Vi and Vim defaults are documented. So now for some options there is still a reference to Vi, while for most there's not and unclear if that's the case because they aren't in Vi or because the defaults are the same. For consistency, there shouldn't be any references to Vi at all if Vi compatibility is not a goal IMHO. Having vim docs without remarks and references about archaic OSes, vi, the 1000 possible compilation options, etc is definitely something I'm looking forward to in Neovim.

Removing documentation for a feature that's still there seemed a bit wrong, so I wanted to do both...

@justinmk 

This is completely separate from `cpoptions`, right? You said this (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/2507#issuecomment-96234798), so I'm not sure whether they are related.

> If someone is using set foo&vi for whatever reason, do we have a good reason to break it?

I don't think supporting that construct makes sense when we've already:
- Removed nocompatible support
- Removed a bunch of Vi references throughout the docs and code
- Removed a few cpoptions options already, with plans of removing the rest (at least it seems that way)

> Also, my feeling on this has always been that it's something that can wait until after first release, when we have 10x as many users. Then it will be easy to know if there's any point in keeping it around. Why add this potential extra friction to new users right now?

I agree with @fmoralesc that it's low priority, but realistically, how many people actually use this? Is there any reason to keep this besides avoiding the theoretical breakage of some people's workflow? We've already broken compatibility on a decent number of things which were arguably useless and/or misfeatures (edcompatible, crypto support, among other things in `vim_diff.txt`), so I don't see why this should be an exception.

To preface this, I'm still not sure if I understand the relationship between vi_def and cpoptions.

@justinmk I read https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/2071#issuecomment-90273078 and now I'm even more confused. You said that `cpo` should be removed, but not as one huge PR; it should be done one cpoption at a time (which I agree with). Could you please clarify why you're okay with doing that, but not with removing `&vi`? I might be misinterpreting you...

> I don't think supporting that construct makes sense when we've already:
> Removed nocompatible support
> Removed a bunch of Vi references throughout the docs and code
> Removed a few cpoptions options already, with plans of removing the rest (at least it seems that way)

We didn't set out to break things just because they have a possible association with Vi. We removed compatibility for specific things where the cost of keeping them outweighed the benefit. 
- We removed nocp because it will allow us to remove numerous code paths which exist only to match Vi bug-for-bug. 
  - The "options profile" known as `&vi` is not such a code path. It's just a pre-defined set of _options that we support_. Removal of this preset doesn't remove any testable code path, nor does it reduce surface area, potential for bugs, or user pain.
- We removed Vi references in the documentation where it made sense to do so. But it is not a goal _per se_ to remove all mentions of Vi.

> We've already broken compatibility on a decent number of things which were arguably useless and/or misfeatures (edcompatible, crypto support, among other things in vim_diff.txt), so I don't see why this should be an exception.

The fact that we broke compatibility in some cases should not be interpreted as a "slippery slope". Each case was measured and justified. Presumably the cost was less than the benefit. 

> clarify why you're okay with doing that, but not with removing `&vi`

I'm not opposed to removing `&vi`, but there is zero reason to do it _right now_. It's not a time-sensitive task: we don't gain anything by removing it now--_and_ we currently lack data on whether it will break plugins. Given that the time-sensitivity is zero, and the risk is greater than zero, that means there is negative reason in favor of doing it until after we have more users.

On the other hand, some tasks _must_ and _should_ be done _before_ the first release.

I am also not in favor of removing any `'cpoption'` that has the same risk:benefit ratio as `&vi`.
Thank you for clarifying everything, I agree on all points.

> and we currently lack data on whether it will break plugins.

Just as an update (I also agree with @justinmk that there are more important things to care about right now): I took a (very) quick look today and found no use of `&vi` anywhere (unlike `&vim`, which pops up a lot in the `set cpo&vim` idiom but which could, I guess, be treated as a no-op).
Closing this in favor of #2676.

labels.description: issues or PRs involving changing the defaults
labels.name: defaults

title: [RFC] Set some defaults early
